description:
Immerse yourself in ArtMASTERS-The Game: A fun, challenging competition between 2 to 4 Players ages 14+ to create famous paintings by famous artists one tile at a time! You don't have to be an artist, or even need to know a lot about art. Your game board Canvas is your guide. With each tile drawn, every Player can be an accomplished artist as a Masterpiece is revealed! It's all in the Tube.

How ArtMASTERS is Played

The Object of the Game is to be the first to complete a Masterwork painting in tiles on your game board, call Frame It! and score. 2 to 4 can play.

You don't have to be an artist, or need to know a lot about art. Your game board Canvas is your guide.

Draw Game tiles from the Tube.
Decide which of three paintings to re-create on your game board Canvas.
Tile-by-tile create a famous artist's Masterpiece.
Be the first to complete a 3x4 inch painting in 12 tiles and call Frame It!  to score.
Only the Player who calls Frame It!  for a completed painting scores for that round.

The Game ends when a Player reaches 500 points.

—description from the publisher

In Mythic Mischief, you play as a faction of Mythic Manor students competing to get as many of the other students caught by the Tomekeeper as you can without getting caught yourself.
Each Faction has its own unique set of abilities to move around the board, move the other factions into the path of the Tomekeeper, and even alter the course of the Tomekeeper by moving bookshelves.
Players are able to upgrade their Faction’s abilities throughout the game by collecting powerful Tomes from around the library.
The winner is the first Team to score 10 Mischief Points or the Team with the most points when the Tomekeeper finishes returning all of the Tomes after lunch!

—description from the publisher

Earthborne Rangers is a customizable, co-operative card game set in the wilderness of the far future. You take on the role of a Ranger, a protector of the mountain valley you call home: a vast wilderness transformed by monumental feats of science and technology devised to save the Earth from destruction long ago. The story of Earthborne Rangers is presented as a branching narrative campaign consisting of a main storyline and a multitude of side stories. In it, you can choose to follow the critical path or to strike off on your own to discover the Valley's many engaging characters, mysterious ruins, and beings both familiar and strange.

You begin by building a deck that reflects your Ranger's interests, personal history, and personality. Then, as you explore the open world and your story takes shape, you augment your deck with improved equipment, refined skills, and the memories of your journey.

Each game session represents one day in the Valley, and you'll pick up in the same location on the map where you rested the night before. Your goal is to either complete one of your available missions or to explore the open world. The session ends when you're either forced to rest (through either fatigue or injury), or you choose to rest for the night.

An individual game session is played in rounds, and those rounds consist of turns. On your turn, you perform one action: either play a card from your hand, or choose an action from a card on the table. Each action allows you to interact thematically and narratively with the world, and each time you take an action, the world comes to life around you. Predators stalk their prey, rain pours from the sky, rocks tumble down the mountain to block your path, and much more.

—description from the publisher

Cook with family or friends a mystery menu to discover throughout the game. At the end of the game, taste your chef's achievement: a 100% vegan menu (starter, main course, dessert)

Difficulty level: 2 out of 3 – Daily chef level
Main ingredients: fennel, button mushrooms, apple  
Other ingredients: passion fruit, lemon, oranges, vegetable milk, ground hazelnuts, chestnuts, mint, vegetable soy cream, cinnamon and flat-leaf parsley

Gameplay

     Choose your mystery menu according to your favorite themes or flavors 
     Build up your brigade of 2 to 6 players 
     Prepare your ingredients with the supplied shopping list 
     Gather your material with the supplied material list 
     Cook step by step and enjoy your chef's menu:


While cooking, spice up your game and try to earn stars by taking up challenges, by answering quizzes or riddles slipped into your game.

Once all the missions have been completed, have a good time while tasting your menu together.

Winning conditions:
The winner is the player or team who scored the most "stars"

Each box contains numbered "Mission" cards, 1 shopping list, 1 equipment list, the rules of the game and its scoreboard.

—description from the publisher (translated)

Cook with family or friends a mystery menu to discover throughout the game. At the end of the game, enjoy your dinner aperitif with 5 appetizer bites.

Difficulty level: 2 out of 3 – Daily chef level
Main ingredients: Gruyere, hazelnut, chervil   
Other ingredients: old-fashioned mustard, olives, mozzarella di bufala, mascarpone, parmesan, lemon, cherry tomatoes, crab, cumin seeds and smoked trout.

Gameplay

     Choose your mystery menu according to your favorite themes or flavors 
     Build up your brigade of 2 to 6 players 
     Prepare your ingredients with the supplied shopping list 
     Gather your material with the supplied material list 
     Cook step by step and enjoy your chef's menu:


While cooking, spice up your game and try to earn stars by taking up challenges, by answering quizzes or riddles slipped into your game.

Once all the missions have been completed, have a good time while tasting your menu together.

Winning conditions:
The winner is the player or team who scored the most "stars"

Each box contains numbered "Mission" cards, 1 shopping list, 1 equipment list, the rules of the game and its scoreboard.

—description from the publisher (translated)

Cook with family or friends a mystery menu to discover throughout the game. At the end of the game, taste your chef's achievement: a 100% vegetarian menu (starter, main course, dessert)

Difficulty level: 2 out of 3 – Daily chef level
Main ingredients: parmesan, eggplant, apple    
Other ingredients: olives, crème fraîche, tomato coulis or juice, orange blossom, lemon, red peppers, celery, button mushrooms, flat-leaf parsley and peppermint.

Gameplay

     Choose your mystery menu according to your favorite themes or flavors 
     Build up your brigade of 2 to 6 players 
     Prepare your ingredients with the supplied shopping list 
     Gather your material with the supplied material list 
     Cook step by step and enjoy your chef's menu:


While cooking, spice up your game and try to earn stars by taking up challenges, by answering quizzes or riddles slipped into your game.

Once all the missions have been completed, have a good time while tasting your menu together.

Winning conditions:
The winner is the player or team who scored the most "stars"

Each box contains numbered "Mission" cards, 1 shopping list, 1 equipment list, the rules of the game and its scoreboard.

—description from the publisher (translated)

Cook with family or friends a mystery menu to discover throughout the game. At the end of the game, taste your chef's achievement: a complete menu (starter, main course, dessert).

Difficulty level: 2 out of 3 – Daily chef level 
Main ingredients: crab, salmon, raspberries   
Other ingredients: Speculoos, pineapple, Philadelphia fresh cheese, kiwis, pink or yellow grapefruit, lemon, sucrine, avocados, pink radishes and shrimps.

Gameplay

     Choose your mystery menu according to your favorite themes or flavors 
     Build up your brigade of 2 to 6 players 
     Prepare your ingredients with the supplied shopping list 
     Gather your material with the supplied material list 
     Cook step by step and enjoy your chef's menu:


While cooking, spice up your game and try to earn stars by taking up challenges, by answering quizzes or riddles slipped into your game.

Once all the missions have been completed, have a good time while tasting your menu together.

Winning conditions:
The winner is the player or team who scored the most "stars"

Each box contains numbered "Mission" cards, 1 shopping list, 1 equipment list, the rules of the game and its scoreboard.

—description from the publisher (translated)

Players take turns moving around the swimming pool playing board collecting one of each of the coloured rings to stack on their 3D llama. Then race to be the first to get your llama to dive into the swimming pool to win the fame!

In this game you are Barbie. A well-known travel company offers you the opportunity to go around the world to collect documentation on the cities visited. A prize is awarded to you for each documentation. You will win if you reach $ 100,000 first, as long as you have at least one ticket for each of the 6 continents.

The players draw 10 letters from a bag with which they must be able to compose the name of a city they want to reach. If they succeed, they move their marker to the city and are rewarded with $ (depending on the city), otherwise they draw another letter and pass the turn to the next player.

Seesaw is a Draughts-inspired elimination game, played on a hexhex board of size 4 or 5. Each player needs, in their own color, a large number of stackable tokens and tiles.

Rules

Overview:
In Seesaw the players command opposing armies of soldiers that can promote. Your army starts out as a single soldier in the bottom corner. This soldier stands on a tile of your color. This tile is your initial promotion area, and it will evolve as you deploy more soldiers. Every time a soldier promotes it grows - first into a 2-stack, then a 3-stack, and so on.

The central idea of Seesaw is the 2-fold significance of stack-size: 
(i) Odd-sized stacks move forwards and even-sized stacks move backwards, and 
(ii) on any given turn, a stack can take as many steps as it likes from 1 up to its size.

This results in soldiers seesawing up and down the board as their strength increases to the point where the game is forced to conclude in one side completely eliminating the other.

How to play:
On your turn, you must either move a stack, or place a new stack.

1. Placing a new stack: 
A newly placed stack will always be of size 1. You may only place a stack on an empty cell next to a cell with a tile of your color. These cells are promotion cells, and each time you place a new stack you first place a tile of your color on that cell. A cell with a tile on it is not considered empty, but tiles never count toward stacks-size.

2. Moving a stack:
You only ever move one stack per turn, but that stack may be able to move several steps or capture several enemy stacks, depending on its size.
The number of steps a stack may take is the number of pieces in it, i.e. its size. A stack may never step onto a cell containing a stack of its color.

2.1 Noncapturing moves: On turns where you do not have to capture an enemy (see below) all the steps a stack takes is either constrained to the 3 upward directions ("forwards") or to the 3 downward directions ("backwards"), depending on the parity of the size of the stack. Up and down have their standard meanings for games where players sit on opposite sides of a board, like in Draughts and Chess.

2.2 Capturing moves: If one or more of your stacks can reach an enemy by lifting the restraint on direction, you must capture such a reachable enemy by replacement. If that stack did not spend all its steps reaching the captured enemy, you can, before you end your turn, spend the left-over steps by making a noncapturing move. However, if yet an enemy is in range immediately after you have captured (counting only the steps left over), you must capture again.

3. Promoting: Your odd-sized stacks promote when they end up on a promotion cell belonging to your opponent at the end of your turn. Your even-sized stacks promote when they end up on a promotion cell belonging to you at the end of your turn. When a stack promotes, you add 1 piece to it.

The object of Seesaw is to capture all your opponent's soldiers. More precisely: If, at the end of your turn, your opponent has no stacks on the board, you have won the game.

In Fire & Stone, players lead their tribe through the Stone Age. They scout new lands, harvest nuts and mushrooms, and finally build villages. The aim of the game is to have the most successful tribe by exploring new lands, building huts, and gathering resources. With the invention of new tools and techniques like ship building or pottery, the expansion of your tribe can even be accelerated.

Each space the scouts can enter contains upside-down discover tokens. When a scout moves on one of those tokens for the first time, the token is revealed and triggers an effect. From now on these tokens can be used as a player action with a different effect. By the end of the game, the player who made the most victory points with villages and accomplishing tasks wins.

Garner is a combinatorial card game for two players where you seek to collect a majority of cards in a majority of suits. It is played with a deck of cards containing 5 suits of 15 numbers each.

Setup:
Shuffle the deck and fan out 25 stacks of 3 cards each in a regular layout of 5 rows and 5 columns. All cards should be visible, and it should be clear which cards are on which layer of the layout. (The 25 top cards in the initial position are on the top layer, and underneath that there are two more layers of 25 cards each.)

Definitions:
Every card belongs in a number group together with all and only those cards which are connected to it by a sequence of orthogonal steps between cards with equal numbers. The members of a group all lie on the same layer.
A suit group is defined the same way, except "number" is replaced with "suit".

Play:
On your turn, you first distribute a number group, then you collect a suit group.

Distribute: Pick up a number group from the current top layer and distribute them anew on the layout. You may not place two of these cards in the same stack, and you may not place them underneath any cards. Other than that, you are free to choose any of the 25 sites in the layout. There is no limit on how many cards there can be at each site.

Collect: Pick up any suit group from the current top layer and store those cards in a personal scoring pile on your side of the board.

Ending the game:
When all cards are collected, the winner is the player whose scoring pile contains the majority of the cards in the majority of the suits.

Slight variations: 

     Add the requirement that all cards (or at least one card) in the chosen number group are in a new position after distributing.
     When distributing, cards must be moved in a straight (diagonal or orthogonal) line.


Decks you can play Garner with:
Rage
Stick 'Em
5°Dimension Playing Card Game
Sluff Off!
Tricky Bid
David & Goliath

Ways of playing with more traditional decks:

(A) 

     9 cards in 3 suits from a standard French deck. 
     Layout: 9 stacks of 3 cards each in a 3x3 grid.


(B) 

     12 cards in 3 suits from a standard French deck. 
     Layout: 9 stacks of 4 cards each in a 3x3 grid. 
     Extra rule: You may never have exactly 6 cards in a suit in your scoring pile. If collecting a suit group would bring the number of cards you have in that suit to 6, you must leave behind a card in the layout, even if it means collecting 0 cards.


(C) 

     13 cards in 3 suits and 9 cards in 1 suit from a standard French deck. 
     Layout: 16 stacks of 3 cards each in a 4x4 grid. 
     Extra rule: The suit with 9 cards is worth half a suit.


(D) 

     9 cards in 4 suits from a standard French deck and 9 cards in a suit form a different deck, like a German deck or Tarot deck. 
     Layout: 15 stacks of 3 cards each in a 3x5 grid.


(E)

     12 cards in 4 suits from a standard French deck and 12 cards in a suit form a different deck, like a German deck or Tarot deck.
     Layout: 20 stacks of 3 cards each in a 4x5 grid.
     Extra rule: You may never have exactly 6 cards in a suit in your scoring pile. If collecting a suit group would bring the number of cards you have in that suit to 6, you must leave behind a card in the layout, even if it means collecting 0 cards.


—description from the designer

Unknot is played on a hexhex board oriented so that there is a horizontal line of adjacent cells between one pair of two opposing corner cells.

Both players share a pool of stones of a single color and take turns placing then onto empty cells.

Placement restrictions.

     The center cell is unplayable throughout the game. 
     Player 1 may not place immediately northwest of a stone. 
     Player 2 may not place immediately northeast of a stone.


The game is over as soon as one player completes a loop of pieces around at least one empty cell. This player is then the winner. The game cannot end in a draw, so can also be played with the opposite goal: The player who completes a loop loses.

—description from the designer

Hoop is played on a hexhex board of size 4-6. Each player has a pool of stones in their own color in addition to a pool of shared neutral stones.

Rules:
Each turn, you first place a neutral stone on an empty cell or replace one of your stones with a neutral stone. Then, you place a stone of your color on an empty cell.

If there are no empty cells, so you cannot place a stone of your color, you may still replace one of your stones with a neutral stone.

Balancing mechanism: On the very first turn, the first player only claims a cell, but does not place a stone.

The game is over as soon as one player completes a loop of neutral stones. The cells inside the loop can have any combination of stones and empty cells – it doesn't matter.

—description from the designer

A game of strategy and intrigue set in 11th Century Byzantium. As a powerful noble you build up your political faction in Constantinople, capital of the ailing Empire. Then, with the Emperor on his deathbed and the Turks harassing the frontier, you must launch your bid for the throne and defeat your rivals on the battlefield to become EMPEROR.

Emperor! has a unique two-phase feature. In phase one players move around a map of the city collecting money, military units and characters to build up their faction. Then, in phase two, the board flips over to the battle phase. Players cash in their cards and sets to build their armies. These are deployed face-down on the battle map. Players then select tactical cards (outflank, charge! etc) for their army and combat is resolved.

Emperor! is card-based with no dice.

—description from the designer

The "Reporterspiel" contains 10 different crossword games with whistle for bright minds.
It starts with an educational reading game for ABC marksmen, goes through a crossword game to a reporter game and an interplay of changing letters.
Since every game is completely different, there is also a different objective in every game. For example, in the crossword game, points are awarded for the color of the field under the letter. In the game of changing letters, for example, a basic word is formed, which can now be formed by replacing, omitting or rearranging letters to form other words. Each letter of these words then counts as one point.

Dynamic Object Solutions is the biggest and most advanced Robot factory in the world. In order to take things to the next level a new CEO must be appointed. A fantastic competition is about to take place. The most notable candidates will build an Artificial Intelligence (AI)! This AI will conduct all operations, develop new technologies, design, production, distribution and sales. The AI who earns the most prestige will be named Dynamic Object Solutions CEO and therefore winner of the game.

In D.O.S. (Dynamic Object Solutions) players manage a set of workers, called AI, that provides for themselves and for the other players with Resources, Performance Points and Data points. These AI will be placed at the main board, to take actions and to collect the aforementioned items. The more powerful the AI the better the action, but at the same time you may give your opponents important points they can take advantage of.
These points will be used at the player board to take actions that will be acquired during the course of the game in the form of cards. Each player can have a very distinct set of actions, and different ways of paying for them.
The game rewards the players for giving each other the means for taking the actions. You need to balance this give and take in order to be more efficient.

—description from the designer

Downfall is a two-player game on the conquest of the Third Reich in World War II. One player controls the Western Allies and the other the Soviet Union in their joint effort to destroy the Axis. Though the two players share the goal of defeating the Reich, each seeks a victory that favors their dominance in post-war Europe. To this end, each player controls two factions:


     The Western player commands the Western Allies faction and the OKH faction, that is the German and minor Axis armies battling the Soviet Union in the east (Oberkommando des Heeres).
     The Soviet player commands the Soviet faction and the OKW faction, that is the German and Italian armies facing the Western allies in the west (Oberkommando der Wehrmacht).


Gameplay is driven by Downfall’s innovative initiative track. The faction with the initiative chooses an order, pays its initiative cost by advancing their marker along the track, and performs the order. Then, the faction with the initiative (based on the updated positions of the markers) chooses the next order. There is no set sequence of play; initiative expenditures determine who goes next. The progress of faction markers along the track also trigger strategic events, changes in weather, and advancement of game turns.

—description from the publisher

A card game like traditional Japanese card game——å¤§å¯Œè±ª, player divided into 2 teams, the player who ran out the card will win the game.
As a classical ladder climbing card game, a player can play cards big than the last player with the same format. If no one can play card, then the last player who played card can choose any card to play.

Ashes is an annihilation game for two players played on a hexhex board with stackable pieces of two colors. The board starts out empty. Still, all you ever do in Ashes is move stacks. This is accomplished by the help of a very liberal understanding of "stack": A single piece is considered a stack of size 1, and an empty cell is considered to contain a stack of size 0.

The basic principle of movement is simple: A stack may move to a cell it can see – i.e. one that is adjacent or joins it in flanking a line of empty cells – if this cell is not occupied by a bigger stack.

It is important that, every time you remove a stack from the board, whether it was one of yours of an enemy stack, you keep one of its pieces in a designated area (off the board) as a reminder. I'll get back to why you need to keep count of removed stacks.

There is an economy to moving whole stacks, which is responsible for stack's coming into and going out of existence (rules for moving proper parts of stacks are given farther down):

Outward movement gains you:
When a move increases the number of steps away from the center cell the moved stack is, it grows by the addition of 1 piece per step further away it ends up. Pieces initially only come onto the board by moving a stack of size 0 at least 1 step away from the center cell.

Non-outward movement costs you:
When a move does not increase the number of steps away from the center cell the moved stack is, it shrinks by the removal of 1 more than 1 piece per step closer it ends up. This means that a stack not moving outward can travel no farther inward than 1 less than its size.

Reproduction tax:
If you increase the number of stacks you own, the resulting size of the newly created stack must be big enough to pay a reproduction tax equal to the number of stacks you have removed from the board (whether friendly or not). For each removed stack, you must subtract a piece from the newly created stack, and the gross size of the stack must be bigger than the number of stacks you have lost, so that its net size is at least 1. If white's reproduction tax is 2, moving a 0-stack three steps away from the center will only result in a 1-stack.

Splitting stacks:
Instead of moving a whole stack, you may move a proper part of a stack. Only the reproduction tax applies to the moving of proper stack parts. This means that a splitting move can get you places a whole stack move can't.

Splitting a stack can (and normally does) increase the number of stacks you own. When it does, a reproduction tax must be paid.

There is no free passing in Ashes. If you can move, you must. This ensures that stacks must eventually (if they are not captured before that) spend all their pieces moving "non-outward", and the reproduction tax will eventually be too high to enter a new stack on the board. The game is over as soon as one player has no stacks on the board and is unable to grow a new stack.

—description from the designer

Göbeklitepe, which has a sacred consciousness, bears the traces of productivity culture. In addition, it is the oldest known cult building group with its beliefs about death and rebirth, the belief that there is life after death, and compositions applied on stones.

My work is an ancient board game consisting of t-columns, animal drawings, figures and the mythical meanings of symbols, which play an important role in the building art of this sacred area.

The game starts from the starting points (A, B). The first player to remove all of the player's pieces from the playing field (C) according to the chosen action plan wins the game.

Player stone and dice are hand modeled with polymer clay.

—description from the designer

You are a privateer seeking to make your fortune.  The tyrannical Imperial Navy is threatening to invade and conquer your island home, robbing you and all the people of the islands of their freedom.  The Empire has no mercy, and has swiftly branded you and the other privateers as pirates.  It is up to you to gain renown by seeking adventure and facing numerous perils, becoming strong enough to rule these islands and repel the Imperial Navy from these waters.  There are other privateers with the same goal as you, and while you all share a similar goal, only one of you can earn the most renown and become the Pirate King or Queen.

Song of the Seas is a pirate adventure sandbox game in which you must stake your claim over the islands by building your Lair and earning the most renown. Sink ships of the tyrannical Imperial Navy, plunder merchant vessels, explore for booty, and encounter legendary perils on the high seas. And don’t forget to choose the right shanty for your crew to sing each day for special boons!

Your goal in Song of the Seas is to earn the most Renown.  The game end is triggered when one player reaches 20 Renown, in which that game round (“Day”) is then completed and final scores tallied.  You also earn 1 Renown for every 100 Gold doubloons you have at the end of the game.

—description from the publisher

Face off in a unique election campaign. Bribe your fellow players, buy power or instigate an insurrection. Everything for the victory!

This card game has three phases in which you must first use your financial resources wisely in order to get the most votes in the final ballot. A variety of mini-games that even integrate your mobile phones provide a varied gameplay experience.

In the first phase you must collect your card deck. Use your money wisely to bid on cards, trade with your fellow players and get lucky in the challenges.

In the second phase your card deck is finalized, you have to pay back loans and hidden goals are achieved.

In the third and final phase you use your cards in a trick taking game. Whoever gets the most card stitches wins the game. A "Stop the Count!" mechanic allows you to end the round early.

—description from the designer

The water stretches to the horizon.
But even though the sea sometimes seems quite calm, the animals of the Baltic Sea know how to pass the time.
Who is beating whom here? Does the starfish beat the seagull or the seal beat a cockle?

Ostsee-Schach is a refreshing, fast chess variant by Dirk Holdorf, in which 2 players aged 8 and up compete with Baltic Sea animals in a tournament. 
You take turns and play until one of you scores 3 victory points and thus wins - or has only one piece left and thus loses.

You get victory points by stacking 3 discs or by moving your own pieces to the opposite edge of the board.
When it is your turn, you move one of your pieces according to the animal you see on it. The figure can consist of only one disc or of two discs, with the upper one belonging to you.
If you move one of your own pieces onto a square where there is already an opponent's piece, you simply place your piece on top of the other one and take it over. If it is then three discs high, you receive a victory point.
However, you may never stack more than 3 discs on top of each other. 
Then it is your opponent's turn until one of you has collected the required three victory points.

It looks like poker ... it feels like poker ... but this poker is toxic!

Toxic People combines a unique blend of draw poker and action cards to bring office politics to a whole new level. You'll need a combination of luck and strategy to emerge the winner in this easy-to-learn party game for 2 to 6 players.

Beat your opponents with a winning hand in a classic game of draw poker. Just don't get too comfortable as a bad bunch of action cards like the cheater and troublemaker are going to mess things up!

You even get to draft the action cards that will be played during the game. Choose the bluffer card if deception turns you on. Choose more sabotage cards (like the bully) if you like to undermine your buddies. Every game can be customized so you'll need different strategies to win.

After the mayhem caused by the action cards, the winner will get to pass the loser a toxic token. The first player with 3 toxic tokens is crowned the loser!

—description from the designer

Each player is assigned a tree that bears 4 ripe apples. The first player to harvest his tree wins the game. Whoever's turn it is rolls a color die and moves an apple. You may only move if you roll the color of your corner, one square ahead. If there are four players, everyone moves to their left neighbor. In the tree itself the apples are not moved. If the player rolls brown, he may move an apple from his tree to his left neighbor's tree, if he rolls black, he takes an apple completely out of the game.

—user summary
Iron Bottom Sound IV is a tactical simulation of night naval surface combat in WW2.

4 different reading dominoes in different difficulty levels to learn to read.


     20 cards where you have to pay attention to certain initial letters.
     20 cards with riddles.
     20 cards with search words.
     20 cards with additional sentences.


Here not only the mechanical reading is trained, but above all the sense-comprehending reading.
Only those who read correctly will find the right card!

The cards of a game are shuffled and distributed to the players. Now the cards have to be placed in such a way that the words or texts match the pictures of the previous card or vice versa... The first to lay down his domino cards wins the game.

The popular tile-laying game RUMMY, now in a German version! As in the famous classic, each player tries to get rid of his tiles as quickly as possible, but in this version, each tile shows a connection between two cities from the German rail network.
From Rostock to Berlin it is 227 km and then on to Potsdam, or rather to Wolfsburg? The player whose turn it is tries to use his tiles to lay routes and to rebuild already played routes in order to get rid of tiles from his own supply.
This creates city connections throughout the entire rail network. Only the first player to get rid of his tiles can win the game!

—user summary

Work together to get Baby, Mommy, and Daddy Shark to the party on Coral Reef. But hurry before the seaweed storm washes everything away. Roll the die and then press the button to determine how many spaces you get the move the Shark and which Shark you get to roll. But be careful, roll a seaweed and you are one step closer to ending the game.

The board features an outline of six characters from the story of Pinocchio (pre-Disney).  Players spin the spinner and try to collect the 6 pieces they need to cover the character outline on the boards. The spinner has a combination of colors and character icons. If the arrow points to a character icon, you can add a piece to your character's outline on the board. If the arrow lands on a color, then you receive a joker tile of that color. If that color is spun again on a future turn, the person holding that color joker tile gets to add a piece to their character's outline on the board. The joker tile is returned to the pool.

The first person to complete their character, wins.

A temple in honor of the gods has just been erected in the heart of an Aztec city. The walls inside this place of worship are to be decorated with paintings of feathered snakes to pay tribute to the gods. An election will be held to determine who is the empire’s most celebrated Cóatl painter so that they may have the honor of decorating the temple walls.

Can you prove your worth? 
 In Cóatl The Card Game, players try to paint the most beautiful and valuable serpent they can. The serpent (or Cóatl) is made up of a Head, a Tail and 8 Body cards.

During their turn, players will play 2 cards to create, then claim, any available patterns on the Prophecy cards. If you complete a Prophecy card that has already been claimed by another player, you will steal it and display it in front of you. You score more points if you create the same pattern multiple times and you may eventually be able to protect that Prophecy card so that it can no longer be stolen.

One game lasts 5 rounds. Players can earn additional victory points if they fulfill the requirements listed on a Temple card. When the last player completes their Cóatl, the player with the most victory points wins.

Cóatl The Card Game also has a solo mode and includes the Golden Feathers expansion, which is compatible with the Cóatl base game!

—description from the designer

Everyone knows them, the bees that fly from flower to flower in summer. They have very important duties. Through pollination, they make a significant contribution to the preservation of biodiversity. But bees are at risk. The death of bees could have far-reaching consequences for all of us. In the game you will learn about the importance of bees for our ecosystem and receive specific tips and information on how we can contribute to the preservation of bees.

Tiles are shuffled, distributed on the honeycombs on the board and turned over one by one. Each player tries to get to the beehive via a path made of green tiles and avoiding the red tiles that can hurt or kill them.  Players roll a die to move around the tiles of the board to find flowers and nectar to strengthen and survive on their long journey back to the beehive in the center of the board.

Bee Good is a co-op board game. Only together can the team ensure that all bees find a way to their beehive. If a player's bee has already arrived in the beehive, he can continue playing and throw the dice for the other players and win jokers. The players win if all bees make it back to the hive.

In this new dynamic fast paced action card game explore forgotten dungeons, keeps and fortresses. Defeat monsters, demons and bandits lurking in the forgotten tunnels through Draggmar and claim fame and riches.

The game is full of tactics and hard decisions that could result in a huge punishment if not played wisely. Dungeons Of Draggmar is a game where you will lose a lot but every victory will make you celebrate and enjoy the next step of your conquest even more!


     An easy to learn experience for new players and fun for experienced ones 
     Replay value and a possibility of choosing the difficulty of the game
     A dynamic, fast, and intense system
     The game is for 1-4 players 


Dungeons Of Draggmar is a fast paced action driven card game. The game takes place in rounds called Dungeon Runs where a player tries to conquer a dungeon using his Heroes and Items and claim the head of the Boss at the end of the run. Of course most of the runs end in failure but then there is always a second chance to be successful!

Earn FAME after every Dungeon Run, hire stronger Heroes, grab better Items and head again straight to the darkness of the deepest dungeon and claim victory!

You need to constantly be prepared, think in advance, sometimes trick or get help from other players and sometimes work alone to achieve your goal!

—description from the publisher

The boards show pictures from Sesame Street or the five letters of the word BINGO in a 5 x 5 grid. Two dice are rolled to determine the field. The first person to cover five pictures horizontally, vertically or diagonally is the winner.

—user summary

Experience exciting puzzles - solve the puzzles to uncover the secret of Treasure Island.
Escape room game with web app for sounds and stories.
Board game for 1-6 adults from 14 years, 90-120 minutes playing time.
Unique 3D game board - scissors, pen, internet access and light source (cell phone or flashlight) required to play.
No destruction of material necessary! However, once you have solved the game, you know the solution.

53 new puzzles - 53 possible victims of the reaper!

A must for all fans of escape games and challenging puzzles
There is a new task waiting for you every week
Puzzles alone, with friends or family
 Dysturbia's last line-up is in mortal danger: a former killer of the Syndicate crime organization, who calls himself "The Reaper", is running amok. He wants to eliminate all enemies of the cartel on his own within a year. Police, public prosecutor's office, journalism - anyone who still stands up for law and truth in Dysturbia will be targeted by the assassin!

Your detective agency Dyscover is also on the hit list. After all, the reaper grants his targets a week's hangover: every Monday he hides a riddle somewhere in town. If you find it and solve it by Sunday evening, he will spare his next victim. Otherwise it has to die. Take your chance!

Alice discovers her likeness on a wanted poster - an aunt is looking for her! Does this aunt really exist? Or is the profile just a trap? Alice has to use all her courage and ingenuity to face her past...

28 pages full of puzzles, action and difficult decisions.

This game presents 5 clues to the identity of a Companion.

With over 500 jewels covering the lives of over 100 Companions, encapsulated in a thrilling clues game, Companion Quest is one of a kind. As a dual game, designed to be played between two people or teams, clues are read out revealing the identity of a Companion.

The faster you guess, the more points you gain. 
The set also contains a bonus Highlights and Villains set which completes the package beautifully.

—description from the publisher

Fast Drive Football (FDF) is a free, one-player, card & dice tabletop game that simulates (American) Pro Football. It's a "drive-by-drive" game, meaning that instead of simulating each individual play, you are simulating one possession at a time. Games take about 15-20 minutes to play once you learn the rules.

"On any given Sunday..." FDF is unique in that most results are driven by team qualities - not precise numerical statistics. This approach allows for the development of a more colorful narrative throughout the game. The game book was designed to ensure that teams perform as they did in real life, but also to allow for the occasional surprise that keeps you coming back to roll just one more game...

—description from the designer

In Crossing Fates 7 different nations fight for supremacy. But temporary alliances give players special powers with which they can score more points, or steal from their opponents.
Cleverly play and match cards for Fate Points and combine totems for various effects. A deceptively simple game with lots of strategy. Will you win the Battle of Fates?

Crossing Fates is a competitive card game for 2 to 4 players.

—description from the publisher

Detective Rummy is a rummy-style card game with a storytelling element revealed in a series of seven different cases. Players take the roles of detectives vying to solve the cases and gain fame.

The story begins at the legendary Rummy Detective Agency, and each case takes you to various locations to solve a crime, including the diner with the best doughnuts in town, the cozy "Quarter to 3 Bar", a ritzy fashion emporium, the circus, the most elite jazz nightclub in town, and more.

The cases in Detective Rummy can be played in two different ways: Campaign Mode and Case Mode. In Campaign Mode, you play all seven cases in order. In Case Mode, you can play cases 2 to 6 as standalone Detective Rummy games one at a time. Since new "Game Changer" cards are discovered in each case in different orders (if at all) each time you play, cases will never resolve the same way twice. You can play both the campaign mode or the individual cases as many times as you like.

Dictopia is a fast-paced word game in a dystopian world played in 5 rounds of 90 seconds.

Language is watched, words are censored. Do you have what it takes to join the Resistance? Each player have 8 cards with 2 letters on it. Use them to create words. Each letter have eyes on it and gives you points. Earn bonus points by having the good number of eyes in your word and by completing special missions of the Resistance.

The winner is the player with the most points at the end of the 5 rounds.

Vacu is a Go-like territory game for two players: Black and White. It is played on the intersections (points) of an initially empty square board. Each player must have access to a sufficient number of stones of their own color.

				
				
					DefinitionsIn these rules, "adjacent" always means "orthogonally adjacent".

A group is a stone along with all other like-colored stones one could reach from it through a series of steps between adjacent stones of its color.

Similarly, a territory is an empty point along with all other empty points one could reach from it through a series of steps between adjacent empty cells. You own a territory if all stones adjacent to points in that territory are of your color.

A liberty of a group is an empty point adjacent to at least one stone in that group.

To flip a group is to replace all its stones with stones of the opposite color.

To suppress a group is to remove all its stones from the board.

Your score is the number of stones of your color on the board, plus the number of points in your territories, plus komi (see below) if you play White.

				
				
					PlayBlack plays first, then turns alternate. On your turn, pass or place a stone of your color on an empty point. If this stone is part of a group with liberties, suppress all enemy groups without liberties. Otherwise, suppress your group without liberties and flip all enemy groups that had no liberties before the suppression. In the latter case, at least one group must be flipped for the move to be legal.

The game ends when either both players pass in succession or a player flips or suppresses the last enemy group on the board. The player with the higher score in the final position wins. The button is used to avoid ties.

If, after a board play, the same board position appears for the third time with the same player to move, the game ends in a draw. A pass is not a board play.

				
				
					Komi and buttonKomi is the whole number of points which is added to White's score at the end of the game as a compensation for playing second. Before the game starts, the first player chooses the value of komi, and then the second player chooses sides. Alternatively, experienced players may agree on a standard value for all games.

The button is a special token which is placed next to the board at the start of the game. On your turn, if neither player has taken the button yet, you may not pass, but you may take the button instead of making a board play. At the end of the game, a half point is added to the score of the player who has taken the button. When checking for repetitions, two identical board positions are still considered different if the button had already been taken in one of them but not in the other.

				
				
					VariantsConvacu: The top and bottom edges of the board are colored black; the left and right edges are colored white. If you have no other moves available, you must pass. Passing is otherwise not allowed. If, at the end of a turn, there is a group touching the two opposite board edges of its color, the owner of that group wins.

In ÐœÐ¸ÑÑÐ¸Ð¾Ð½ÐµÑ€ÑÐºÐ¸Ðµ Ð¿ÑƒÑ‚ÐµÑˆÐµÑÑ‚Ð²Ð¸Ñ Ð°Ð¿Ð¾ÑÑ‚Ð¾Ð»Ð° ÐŸÐ°Ð²Ð»Ð°, ("Missionary travels of the Apostle Paul"), the players will embark on a fascinating adventure in the footsteps of the missionary journey of the apostle.

It will begin in Jerusalem, from where Saul went to Damascus to begin massacring the Christians of this city. And it will continue in the cities of Asia Minor and Europe. 
Many adventures await them: ferocious lions, robbers and even a shipwreck. 
The winner is the player who overcomes all obstacles and gets to Rome first.

During the game, they will be able to get acquainted with the letters of the Apostle Paul, addressed to different churches, which he founded during his missionary travels.

So, imagine that you are the apostle Paul, and off you go! You will face many difficulties, but fulfill your mission - to bring the good news of Jesus Christ to the peoples of the Balkan Peninsula and Asia Minor.

—description from the publisher (translated)

"Gather the characters from Alice's story and start your own little funny tale!"

In Gather Round! Alice in the Wonder Museum, each player has a hand of cards featuring small and large portraits of seven characters from the books by Lewis Carrol. The game has a whimsical graphic design, utilizing the original illustrations by John Tenniel.

The goal is to have a hand of five cards where every small portrait matches a large portrait. Upon building a complete hand, the player scores a point for each small portrait in their hand. The first player to 20 points wins.

Each player keeps four cards in their hand. On your turn, you draw from the deck or the discards of other players. Trying to build a set of matching cards in hand is a puzzle, with each card having one large portrait and one to three small portraits. If your turn ends without creating a completed hand, discard one card face up in front of you. Be careful, because other players will be able to choose from your discards, but you cannot.

Dragões: Guardiões da Memória is a memory game designed for three children from 6+.

One of the children will be the the guardian, rolling the 4 custom dice showing the 4 parts of a dragon (head, torso, legs and tail) behind a shield. After that, the guardian raise the shield allowing the other two to see the dice results (the color of each dragon part) for a time between 5 and 15s (depending on the age of the players).

When the shield is placed again in position, hiding the dice, the players (not the guardian) must create the result of the dice using tiles representing the dragon parts in the correct colors.
If one child correctly assemble the dragon, he or she receive one dragon egg. The first player to obtain 3 dragon eggs become the new guardian and the game starts again.

There are variants for older children also, including one where the players must start the assemble according to a coin result, from head or from tail. There is also variants for 1 and 2 players.

Thank you for showing interest in our second game release. These “veteran game mechanics” have been adapted to a “universal” rule set to play a variety of time periods. This book is a stand alone product that does not require any other purchases from us to use your own miniatures collection. Everything you need is right there to play without days of making up your own stuff.

These mechanics been a fun and quick way to play Science Fiction and Modern games with our friends since 2005. We even adapted it to work well in a Victorian “Colonial” setting with a few tweeks. These rules ARE NOT an exact replica of the weapons and equipment of any Era, nor a Hollywood enhancement, but rather to provide a reasonable simulation for enjoyable gameplay.

Quickly about the mechanics... Each figure has a certain number of “actions” each round – in addition they can also react during the enemy’s play. This produces a less static game, but also one that is not so fluid people are never sure where things stand.

This book contains all the Rules you need to play on 4 page large font handy flow chart. As well as a comprehensive Weapons Chart from Spears to Fusion Cannons. In addition are Generic Unit cards you can copy out - or download from our website or facebook - to slip into a standard playing card sleeve for east reference. Not to mention sample Army Lists, Scenarios, and so forth to keep you busy for a little while.

Our goal is to provide you enough material to actually play with, so you do not have to make things up on your own. Our website will contain other fan made products to official support for the game. IE: More scenarios and unit cards.

Thanks to modern publishing techniques, we will be finishing up the following OPTIONAL "Setting Books". Each will include our own world "fluff", specific Unit Cards tailored to the era, Scenarios, and even some old school Terrain tips and Miniature suggestions:


     Our "Victorian Era" setting book will cover my favorite Era of play. From 1870 thru the 1930's across those various Historical periods up through World War 1. Even a dash of information if you prefer to play Victorian Science Fiction. It will contain some of my unpublished materials from the "Battlefield: Evolution" book that would have covered this topic. 
     Our "Science Fiction" setting book will cover man to man, and man to alien, combat in the near and far future. Scenarios and ideas to cover our own Universe, as well as suggestions for your own. 
     Our "World War 2 to Modern" setting book will cover from World War 2 up till the 1990's. It will handle both the Historical needs of those games, as well as, the ability to play "Pulp" action around your favorite stories and comics with lots of blue and red lasers. Including a cross over of our Solo play and Co-Op play material from "Zombie-a-go-go" before the Tidalwave of Zombie games. 
     Our "Cthulhu Mythos" setting book will go hand in hand with the "Xothic Wars" products that I co-designed. Each chapter will cover each one of the races covered with Unit Cards, Scenarios, and suggested miniature ranges. 
     Our "Ancients and Fantasy" setting book will cover things like my favorite Roman historical period, to any range of Fantasy settings and variants. 
     Our "Black Powder" setting book will cover Samurai, Pirates, and from the Seven Years War up through the American Civil War. It will feature my campaign for the 1860-1962 skirmishes in the American Southwest. 


—description from the publisher

The players start at space 1 in Hamburg. The first to reach space 80 wins the game. Movement is determined by a spinner in the center of the game board. On some spaces events hinder or benefit the players.

This game was published about 1903.

—user summary
